article.title: A multi-omics longitudinal study of the murine retinal response to chronic low-dose irradiation and simulated microgravity
funding: NASA Human Research Program Grant No. 80NSSC18K0310
article.abstract: The space environment includes unique hazards like radiation and microgravity which can adversely affect biological systems. We assessed a multi-omics NASA GeneLab dataset where mice were hindlimb unloaded and/or gamma irradiated for 21 days followed by retinal analysis at 7 days, 1 month or 4 months post-exposure.

sections.introduction: Spaceflight hazards such as microgravity and space radiation are anticipated to impact biological systems and could potentially affect crew health and performance both in mission and once astronauts return to Earth.
sections.methods: The original study was conducted at Loma Linda University following recommendations in the Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals50 and was approved on April 30, 2014, by the Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC) at Loma Linda University (Protocol number 8130028).
sections.results: Post-exposure timepoints had different global expression patterns that were visible in principal component analysis where samples clustered more closely based on time point/age of mice instead of the exposure condition (Supplementary Fig. 1A).
sections.discussion: Spaceflight is an environment to which Earth-based biological systems have not yet adapted. Changes in gravity as well as radiation exposure that differs from terrestrial radiation both in terms of intensity and type, are the two primary naturally occurring hazards the human body contends with during space travel.

article.insights_summary: The study assessed the effects of chronic low-dose irradiation and simulated microgravity on the murine retinal response. The results showed different global expression patterns at different time points and identified genes and processes related to retinal function and inflammatory response.
